childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1950-1962

The smell of Bactine on scraped knees. The heft of a genuine Davy Crockett coonskin cap. The satisfying click of Lincoln Logs locking into place. This cohort's childhood had a weight to it—everything was made of metal, wood, or genuine leather. Plastic was for poor people.

At four, this cohort was watching Howdy Doody in the living room of a neighbor who had a TV—this cohort's family probably didn't own one yet. By six, this cohort had this cohort's own set, and Captain Kangaroo became this cohort's morning routine. This cohort knew the Mouseketeers by name: Annette, Cubby, Karen, Bobby. The Mickey Mouse Club theme song is still lodged somewhere in this cohort's brain, ready to surface at any moment.

This cohort's toys were built to last generations. Erector Sets with actual metal girders. Lionel trains that ran on their own track around the Christmas tree. Silly Putty that could copy the Sunday comics. Mr. Potato Head—the original version where this cohort stuck plastic parts into real potatoes, because that was apparently fine. Slinky, which this cohort walked down every staircase in the house until it got tangled beyond repair.

At seven, this cohort was crouched under this cohort's school desk during duck-and-cover drills, learning that a wooden desk would somehow protect this cohort from nuclear annihilation. Sputnik launched that same year, and suddenly the Soviets were overhead, beeping, watching. This cohort's teachers said we were losing the space race. This cohort's parents said the Communists could strike at any moment. This cohort went outside to play cowboys and Indians anyway.

This cohort ate Campbell's soup straight from the can if Mom wasn't looking. Swanson TV dinners on aluminum trays—salisbury steak with the apple cobbler touching the corn. Jiffy Pop on the stovetop, watching the foil dome expand like magic. Tang for breakfast because astronauts drank it, which made it scientific. Hostess Twinkies in this cohort's lunchbox, and nobody worried about expiration dates.

Summer meant catching fireflies in Mason jars, running through the DDT fog when the mosquito truck came (nobody told this cohort not to), and staying outside until the streetlights flickered on. This cohort's mother didn't know where this cohort was for hours at a time, and that was called parenting.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Cinderella was in theaters the year this cohort was born—Disney's first feature since Bambi. Patti Page was singing 'Tennessee Waltz.' Peanuts debuted in seven newspapers, introducing Charlie Brown's quiet despair to a nation that wouldn't understand it for decades. The culture of 1950 was bobby socks and malt shops on the surface, nuclear anxiety underneath.

At five, this cohort heard Elvis Presley on the radio singing 'That's All Right,' and something shifted. By six, he was on Ed Sullivan, but the cameras only showed him from the waist up because his hips were too dangerous. This cohort's parents were horrified. This cohort were transfixed. Rock and roll was the first thing this cohort's generation owned that adults didn't control—and they hated that.

This cohort grew up on TV westerns: Gunsmoke, Wagon Train, Have Gun—Will Travel, The Rifleman. Every kid had a cap gun and a cowboy hat. This cohort wanted to be Roy Rogers or Davy Crockett or the Lone Ranger. This cohort sang the theme songs. This cohort knew that good guys wore white hats and bad guys wore black, and the world was that simple.

At eight, this cohort watched Leave It to Beaver premiere and wondered why the Cleavers' house was so much nicer than theirs. Father Knows Best taught this cohort that dads had all the answers. Ozzie and Harriet convinced this cohort that every family sang together. None of it matched reality, but this cohort didn't question the gap yet.

Movies were events. At six, this cohort saw The Ten Commandments and thought Charlton Heston actually was Moses. At nine, Ben-Hur and its chariot race. Science fiction meant The Day the Earth Stood Still and Invasion of the Body Snatchers—aliens that were really Communists, conformity that was really the suburbs. This cohort didn't catch the metaphors until later.

Then this cohort turned thirteen. November 22, 1963. This cohort were in school when the announcement came. JFK was dead. This cohort watched Walter Cronkite cry on television. Three months later, the Beatles landed at JFK airport, and four mop-topped British kids made this cohort forget, briefly, that the president had been shot in the head. By fifteen, Dylan went electric at Newport. By seventeen, the Summer of Love. By nineteen, Woodstock. This cohort's generation invented the counterculture, and this cohort was there—or wished this cohort was.

technology.html:
This cohort's Technology Timeline

The party line. If this cohort had to explain this to this cohort's grandchildren, where would this cohort even start? Multiple families sharing one phone line, picking up the receiver quietly to see if Mrs. Henderson was still gossiping with her sister, waiting this cohort's turn to make a call. Privacy was a concept that hadn't been invented yet.

At four, this cohort's family probably didn't own a television. By eight, this cohort did—a hulking console with a 12-inch screen that took ninety seconds to warm up. Three channels, and they all signed off at midnight with the national anthem. This cohort adjusted the rabbit ears endlessly, wrapped them in tinfoil, stood in specific spots in the room because somehow that helped the reception. Color TV arrived when this cohort was fourteen, but this cohort didn't own one until this cohort was in this cohort's twenties.

At seven, Sputnik crossed the sky, beeping in Russian, and the world changed. This cohort were suddenly enrolled in 'New Math' that this cohort's parents couldn't help with because the Soviets were beating us. At eleven, this cohort watched Alan Shepard become the first American in space. At twelve, John Glenn orbited the Earth. At nineteen, Armstrong walked on the moon—July 20, 1969—and this cohort watched it live on that same TV that took ninety seconds to warm up.

This cohort learned to type on a manual typewriter, hitting the keys hard enough to make an impression through the ribbon. Carbon paper for copies. White-Out for mistakes. The hum and clatter of an office typing pool was the soundtrack of professional work. When electric typewriters arrived, they felt luxurious. When word processors arrived in this cohort's thirties, they felt like witchcraft.

Computers entered this cohort's life in this cohort's mid-thirties, beige boxes that ran MS-DOS and required commands this cohort had to memorize. At forty-five, the World Wide Web arrived—dial-up modems, AOL discs in every mailbox, waiting three minutes for a single image to load. This cohort learned email in this cohort's late forties, grudgingly. This cohort got a cell phone in this cohort's fifties, a smartphone in this cohort's sixties. Each step felt like catching a train that was already moving.

This cohort've witnessed more technological change than any generation in human history. Born before TV was common, this cohort've lived to see video calls, artificial intelligence, and computers in every pocket. The world this cohort was born into no longer exists, and the world this cohort inhabit now would be incomprehensible to this cohort's parents. This cohort adapted. This cohort always do.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Korea had already erupted by the time this cohort took this cohort's first breath. This cohort's father might have served; 5.7 million Americans did. The war that would later be called 'forgotten' was very much remembered in this cohort's household—another conflict, another draft, another set of young men shipped overseas just five years after the last war ended. This cohort were three when the armistice was signed. Too young to remember, old enough to absorb the anxiety.

At four, this cohort watched the Army-McCarthy hearings on television—or rather, this cohort's parents watched while this cohort played on the floor. 'Have you no sense of decency?' became a phrase adults repeated. Blacklists and loyalty oaths were real things that affected real people. This cohort's parents were careful about what they said, who they associated with, what books they kept visible. The 1950s conformity wasn't just cultural preference—it was survival.

At four, the Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that segregated schools were unconstitutional. At seven, nine Black students integrated Little Rock Central High School while the National Guard blocked the door. This cohort watched it on television—federal troops escorting teenagers through mobs of screaming white adults. This cohort were learning what this cohort's country actually was.

At thirteen, the announcement came—JFK had been shot in Dallas. This cohort's generation's defining moment, the end of postwar innocence. The generational identity section captures what that day meant. What followed: escalating Vietnam, cities burning, a decade of assassinations that proved the fragility this cohort'd just discovered wasn't temporary.

At eighteen, this cohort registered for the draft. Vietnam wasn't theoretical—it was this cohort's birthday pulling a number, this cohort's friends coming home different or not coming home at all, this cohort's choice between service, deferment, protest, or Canada. The war killed 58,220 Americans. Millions of Vietnamese. This cohort knew people on both sides of that number.

At eighteen, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated. At eighteen, Bobby Kennedy was shot in a hotel kitchen. At eighteen, Chicago police beat protesters at the Democratic Convention while the whole world watched. The year 1968 packed enough trauma for a decade. This cohort lived through it before this cohort could legally drink. At {{AGE_AT_911}}, this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. At seventy, COVID. History never stopped happening to this cohort.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Here's what nobody tells younger generations: the world this cohort entered at twenty-two wasn't fair either. But the unfairness worked in this cohort's favor. This cohort just didn't know it at the time.

This cohort graduated high school in 1968 or college around 1972, stepping into a job market that actually had jobs. Entry-level meant entry-level. A state college cost $400 a semester, and this cohort could pay it with a summer job. The guy in HR didn't require three years of experience for a position called 'trainee.' Companies hired people and kept them—not out of kindness, but because that's how business worked.

The path was visible: get hired, work this cohort's way up, get promoted every few years, retire with a pension. Not exciting, but predictable. A single income bought a house, supported a family, put kids through school. The ladder had rungs. Each rung led somewhere. The financial section details how radically that math has changed.

This cohort worked through stagflation in the seventies, watched manufacturing jobs start their long decline, survived the recessions of '81 and '82. By this cohort's forties, this cohort was management—either doing the downsizing or worrying about being downsized. 'Corporate loyalty' stopped meaning what this cohort's father thought it meant. Jack Welch became a management guru by firing 100,000 people at GE. The contract was breaking, but this cohort's generation mostly got out before it shattered.

This cohort learned computers in this cohort's mid-thirties, reluctantly. The secretaries who actually knew how to use the new systems suddenly had leverage. This cohort adapted to email in this cohort's late forties, to the internet in this cohort's fifties. This cohort weren't a digital native, but this cohort weren't a digital refugee either—this cohort learned enough to stay relevant, even if this cohort's kids rolled their eyes at this cohort's questions.

If this cohort followed the script, this cohort retired with a pension—an actual defined-benefit pension, the kind that guarantees income until this cohort die. This cohort's children have 401(k)s and anxiety. This cohort had health insurance that covered things. This cohort had job security that wasn't an oxymoron. This cohort were the last generation to work in a world where companies believed they owed employees something. This cohort didn't build that world. But this cohort benefited from it.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

This cohort's parents remembered the Depression with their bodies—the way scarcity carved itself into muscle memory. They saved string, reused aluminum foil, kept coffee cans full of coins. 'Waste not, want not' wasn't a saying; it was survival strategy. This cohort inherited their caution even as this cohort lived in the most prosperous economy in human history.

The numbers tell a story younger generations struggle to believe. This cohort's first house, purchased around 1976, cost maybe $35,000—roughly 2.5 times this cohort's annual salary. This cohort put 10% down. This cohort's monthly mortgage was less than a week's pay. That same house is worth $450,000 now, and this cohort still don't entirely understand how that happened. This cohort just lived there and paid this cohort's bills.

This cohort bought stock when stock meant something—shares in companies that made things, employed people, paid dividends. The market was where serious money went. Mutual funds were exotic. By the time 401(k)s replaced pensions in the 1980s, this cohort'd already built a foundation. This cohort contributed because this cohort could, not because this cohort had to. Compound interest did the rest.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 crash hit. This cohort watched this cohort's retirement accounts drop 40% in six months. This cohort delayed vacations. This cohort worried. But this cohort didn't lose this cohort's house, because this cohort'd paid it off. This cohort didn't lose this cohort's job, because this cohort was close enough to retirement that laying this cohort off triggered age discrimination concerns. This cohort recovered. Many of this cohort's children's generation did not.

Here's the truth nobody wants to say out loud: this cohort're rich by accident. Not all of this cohort, but statistically, as a cohort. This cohort didn't work harder than this cohort's kids. This cohort worked during different economic conditions. Assets appreciated while this cohort held them. Salaries for younger workers stagnated. This cohort got lucky. Luck feels like merit when this cohort're on the right side of it.

This cohort's grandchildren can't afford houses. This cohort's children are still paying student loans in their forties. They see this cohort's paid-off mortgage, this cohort's pension, this cohort's nest egg, and they see math that no longer adds up. The ladder this cohort climbed has been pulled up. Acknowledging that doesn't diminish what this cohort built. But pretending the same financial path is still possible for them? That's where generational tension begins.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

This cohort's 20s (1970-1980): Vietnam was still happening when this cohort turned twenty. This cohort either served, got a deferment, protested, or fled—there was no neutral option. This cohort married young by today's standards (average age: 23 for men, 21 for women) because that's what people did. This cohort bought this cohort's first house around 1976 for a price that now sounds like a typo. This cohort had this cohort's first child. The script was clear: job, marriage, house, kids. This cohort followed it because deviating was barely imaginable.

This cohort's 30s (1980-1990): Reagan. Morning in America. The economy recovered from the malaise of the 1970s, and suddenly it was acceptable to want things again. This cohort were raising kids, climbing corporate ladders, paying mortgages that felt manageable. This cohort's children grew up in the prosperous 1980s, watching this cohort succeed, assuming they'd inherit the same opportunities. They wouldn't.

This cohort's 40s (1990-2000): The Cold War ended when this cohort was thirty-nine. The Berlin Wall came down on live television, and the existential threat this cohort'd lived with since duck-and-cover drills simply... evaporated. This cohort's kids were teenagers or leaving for college. The internet arrived, confusing but clearly important. The 1990s felt like victory—America had won, history was over, this cohort's 401(k) was growing. Peak earning years. Peak optimism. It wouldn't last.

This cohort's 50s (2000-2010): This cohort were fifty-one when the towers fell. This cohort watched it happen live, like everyone else. The optimism of the 1990s died that morning. This cohort's kids—if this cohort had them—were draft age for wars that would last twenty years. At fifty-eight, the financial system collapsed. This cohort watched retirement accounts lose 40% of their value. Some of this cohort delayed retirement. Some lost houses. The Depression this cohort's parents remembered suddenly felt less distant.

This cohort's 60s (2010-2020): Retirement, if this cohort could afford it. Grandchildren, if this cohort's kids could afford to have them. This cohort's parents, if still living, needed care—and this cohort was the generation doing the caring. Medicare, Social Security, the systems this cohort'd paid into this cohort's whole life—suddenly everyone was debating whether they'd exist for this cohort's kids. This cohort were caught between generations, responsible for both.

This cohort's 70s and beyond (2020+): COVID made this cohort's generation the canaries in the coal mine. This cohort were the high-risk population, the nursing home deaths, the reason younger people were supposed to stay home. Some of this cohort's friends didn't make it. The isolation was brutal. Now this cohort're seventy-four or older, navigating a world that moves too fast, that values youth, that treats this cohort's experience as obsolete. This cohort've outlived so many. That's victory, even when it doesn't feel like it.

generational_identity.html:
The Boomer Generation

Baby Boomer. The name itself tells this generation something—this generation was the boom, the demographic explosion, the 76 million Americans born between 1946 and 1964. This generation's parents survived the Depression and won World War II, and they celebrated by having more children than any generation before or since. Boomers were their reward for winning. That's a lot to live up to.

Boomers was going to change everything. Boomers protested Vietnam, fought for civil rights, invented the counterculture, and told anyone over thirty not to trust this generation. Boomers believed—genuinely believed—that this generation's generation would be different. Boomers'd end war. Boomers'd end poverty. Boomers'd end racism. Boomers was young and righteous and utterly certain.

Then came November 22, 1963. Boomers was thirteen, in school, when the announcement came over the PA system. President Kennedy had been shot in Dallas. Boomers watched this generation's teacher cry. Boomers walked home through streets that were too quiet. That weekend, this generation saw Jack Ruby shoot Lee Harvey Oswald on live television—the first murder broadcast to a national audience. Something broke that November, and it stayed broken. The innocence of the postwar era ended in a motorcade in Dallas, and this generation's generation grew up in the aftermath.

What happened next is complicated. Some of this generation stayed true to those ideals. Most of this generation got jobs, got mortgages, got suburban houses, got comfortable. The radicals became consultants. The hippies became stockbrokers. The revolution became nostalgia. By the time Reagan was elected in 1980, this generation's generation had become the establishment this generation once vowed to overthrow.

The narrative about this generation's generation is harsh, and some of it is deserved. Boomers pulled the ladder up behind this generation. Boomers voted for tax cuts that defunded the public goods this generation'd benefited from. Boomers hollowed out unions, privatized pensions, deregulated finance. The economic mobility this generation enjoyed? Boomers made it harder for the generations that followed. Not all of this generation, but enough of this generation.

But the narrative is also incomplete. Boomers also marched for civil rights when marching got people killed. Boomers was drafted into a war this generation didn't believe in and came home to a country that blamed this generation for it. Boomers raised this generation's kids with more emotional awareness than this generation received. Boomers built the infrastructure—physical and institutional—that subsequent generations use to criticize this generation.

Boomers're the most politically powerful generation in American history. Every president from Clinton through Biden has been a Boomer. Boomers vote in higher numbers than anyone else. The world is still, for now, arranged around this generation's preferences. That won't last much longer.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Did this generation ever sit by the phone, waiting for it to ring, because calling someone first meant this generation liked them more than they liked this generation? Did this generation ever rehearse what this generation'd say, heart pounding, before dialing? Did this generation's mother pick up the extension and refuse to get off?

Courtship in this generation's era was structured. Boomers didn't 'hang out'—this generation dated. Dinner, movie, maybe parking at the Point afterward. Boys paid. Girls dressed up. Everybody knew the rules, even if nobody wrote them down. Going steady meant his class ring on a chain around this generation's neck. Breaking up meant giving it back. Simple. Brutally simple.

Boomers married young—average age 23 for men, 21 for women in 1970. Divorce was shameful, which meant a lot of unhappy marriages stayed together out of obligation rather than choice. This generation's generation changed that. By the time this generation's kids were teenagers, divorce was common, sometimes expected. Was that progress? Depends who this generation ask.

This generation's generation mainstreamed living together before marriage—'shacking up,' this generation's parents called it, with all the disapproval they could muster. Boomers tried to raise this generation's kids with more freedom than this generation'd had, more openness about sex, more emotional honesty. How'd that work out? Mixed reviews.

Boomers've buried friends. Maybe a spouse. Boomers've watched the people this generation grew up with disappear, one by one. This generation's address book is full of names this generation can't call anymore. Nobody prepares this generation for that part—the way this generation's world shrinks as this generation age, the way loneliness settles in even when this generation're surrounded by people who love this generation.

Communication has changed more in this generation's lifetime than in all of human history before it. Boomers went from party lines to smartphones, from handwritten letters to text messages, from calling long-distance once a month (expensive!) to FaceTiming grandchildren who live across the country. Boomers adapted. Boomers didn't have a choice. But sometimes this generation miss the weight of a handwritten note, the anticipation of a letter in the mailbox, the way silence used to feel like connection instead of absence.

blind_spots.html:
This generation's Generational Blind Spots

Boomers survived things. Boomers really did. The Cold War, Vietnam, the assassinations, the social upheaval. Boomers built careers and families during actual hardship. But surviving things doesn't automatically grant wisdom, and the confidence that comes from survival can look like arrogance to people fighting different battles.

The economy this generation navigated no longer exists, but this generation talk about it like it does. The advice this generation offer—work hard, stay loyal, be patient—was true in this generation's era. It describes conditions that no longer exist. When this generation repeat this generation's playbook, this generation're not offering guidance—this generation're describing a world that ended decades ago. This generation's children and grandchildren don't need to know how this generation did it. They need this generation to understand why the same approach won't work for them.

Boomers invented youth culture, and then this generation refused to stop being the youth. Boomers're still the target demographic. Classic rock stations play this generation's music. Movies reboot this generation's franchises. Politicians court this generation's votes above everyone else's. Boomers've dominated American culture for sixty years, and this generation don't notice the dominance because it feels like normalcy. Gen X has spent their entire lives waiting for this generation to get out of the way. Millennials gave up waiting.

The individualism this generation embraced had costs this generation didn't see. 'Pull themselves up by their own bootstraps' works great when the boots are affordable and the straps are attached. When this generation deregulated industries, privatized public goods, and voted for tax cuts, this generation was solving this generation's problems. Boomers created different problems for everyone who came after.

Climate change happened on this generation's watch. Not exclusively—earlier generations started the engines—but this generation had the information and the power to act, and mostly this generation didn't. This generation's grandchildren will inherit that failure. Some of them already blame this generation. That blame might not be fair, individually, but collectively? The carbon was burned while this generation controlled the thermostat.

Here's the hardest blind spot: this generation don't know what this generation don't know. The same confidence that helped this generation build careers and raise families makes it hard to admit this generation might be wrong, might be out of touch, might not understand the world anymore. Listening is harder than advising. Uncertainty is harder than conviction. But this generation's grandchildren don't need another lecture. They need to know this generation're still learning, too.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} Americans were born the same year as this generation—part of the 76 million classified as Baby Boomers. Boomers're the second-largest generation in American history, outnumbered only by Millennials (and soon, Gen Z). Boomers've held cultural and economic power for so long it feels like gravity—invisible, inevitable, eternal. It isn't.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): This generation's parents and older siblings. They grew up in the Depression, fought in World War II, built the postwar suburbs. They trusted institutions—government, corporations, churches. Boomers questioned them. They valued conformity; this generation invented rebellion as a lifestyle brand. They had smaller families; this generation had bigger ones. They saved obsessively; this generation spent more freely. They think this generation're spoiled. Boomers think they're repressed. Both of this generation might be right.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): The latchkey kids, the MTV generation, the overlooked middle child of American demographics. They grew up in this generation's shadow and never escaped it. By the time they reached career age, this generation occupied all the leadership positions. By the time they hit middle age, this generation still hadn't retired. They're practical, cynical, skeptical of this generation's idealism because they watched idealism curdle into hypocrisy. They'll take over eventually—if there's anything left.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): The generation that can't stop blaming this generation—and has reasons to. They graduated into the Great Recession, bought houses at peak prices (if at all), carry student debt this generation never imagined. They entered a workforce this generation restructured to favor shareholders over workers. When they complain about economic conditions, this generation hear ingratitude. When this generation offer advice, they hear condescension. The gap between this generation isn't about work ethic. It's about math.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): This generation's grandchildren, mostly. They've never known a world before smartphones, before 9/11, before climate change was undeniable. They're anxious in ways this generation don't fully understand and pragmatic in ways this generation might respect. They don't expect the system to work for them. They're building around it. They'll either save the world or watch it burn, and they know which outcome is more likely. They need this generation's resources more than this generation's advice—though they won't say it that bluntly.

This generation's generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. This ratio is historically unprecedented. The wealth transfer to younger generations—often called the 'Great Wealth Transfer'—will be the largest in human history. Whether that money gets passed down, taxed, or spent on end-of-life care will shape the economy for decades. No pressure.

year_events: Senator McCarthy began Communist witch hunts
First Diners Club credit card issued
